In a video address to the Irish Parliament, Ukraine's leader repeated calls for harsher punishments and accused Moscow of preventing provisions from reaching those in need. Anka Ula reports now. A plea for tougher sanctions against Russia. Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky appeared before the Irish Parliament to ask for help convincing Western leaders to respond to Russian war crimes in his country.

sentences.sentence: Well, let's get a view from a Ukrainian MP now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

But certainly we are desperately waiting for more weapons from the West.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07

It's even hard to say how many, because Russians, their clothes and lingerie was all around and near the outer route. So we can just understand what had happened probably before they were killed. And after these Russians put them on tires and tried to burn their bodies, and partly they succeed. So I can't even tell you how many women I saw in one place. Just imagine this picture. And that is so horrific. That is so terrible. But that I saw by my own eyes. That, of course, is a horrific image.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The European Parliament has been discussing the proposed fifth round of sanctions on Russia that Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced on Tuesday. Now the measures target Russian coal and shipping, but not imports of oil and gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But speaking in Strasbourg today, Council President Charles Michel said that sanctions on those sectors will be necessary sooner or later.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The proposed measures on Russian energy have not been met with unified support from bloc members.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ursula von der Leyen says there will be more sanctions to come.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: These sanctions will not be our last sanctions. As I said already yesterday, yes, we've now banned coal, but now we have to look into oil and we have to look into the revenues that Russia gets from the fossil fuels and we really have to make an effort, for example, to take a share to the escrow, to an escrow banking system, so that we will really limit the source of revenues from Russia, from fossil fuels. It has to be an end with that. And this is the next step we will have to take together. Well, joining me from Strasbourg is our correspondent Shona Murray. Shona, we were hearing about those further proposed EU sanctions but it seems that not all EU member states are in agreement. What can you tell us. Well there was a meeting of EU ambassadors today where those sanctions that were announced yesterday were supposed to be rubber stamped. That didn't happen. There's another meeting tomorrow. But I don't think that there's major divisions. There's a consensus over coal. I mean it's not that difficult. Four billion euro a year. And there's just concerns over some of the practicalities around shipping. If you ban Russian ships coming into EU ports it's actually very difficult to know which ones are Russian because often they could be Russian ownership would have a Maltese flag or an Italian flag. So some practicalities. But I think what's interesting, Helena, is when we move on to the difficult conversation about oil and gas, and that is going to happen soon, as we heard there, particularly because we've seen what happened in Bucha. And there is a fear and an expectation that what we saw in Bucha is only the start of things to come. So what I've heard is Austria and Germany, two of the biggest holdouts, are moving in the direction of banning oil and gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And I caught up with Manfred Weber, who's a German MEP, leader of the European People's Party group, and he said that now is the time to go much further on sanctions against Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The MEP group is clear. We need now strong messages on the energy sector, and that means coal and oil has to be immediately stopped.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And for the gas, we are still in discussions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The group will decide this evening, but we want to increase pressure towards Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So tell us about the oil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I mean, particularly coming from Germany, where you have huge reliance on Russian oil, and also from a manufacturing point of view, oil is so important.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: How have you managed to deal with that? How will you deal without Russian oil and also from a manufacturing point of view oil is so important. How have you managed to deal with that? How will you like deal without Russian oil? We know that for coal and for oil we have a global market so we can compensate the deliveries from Russia more easily but the more important thing is that after Bucha everything is different and we have to recognize this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Having the war crimes now in mind we have to stand up and we have to speed up and we have to recognize this. Having the war crimes now in mind, we have to stand up and we have to speed up and we have to tell our citizens the truth that will cost us something.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So the energy price increase, although the inflation which we are facing in Europe is an effect of this Putin driven war and that means if we want to defend our European way of life we have to invest also. It costs us something.

Obviously, he's not in government, but really making the point that the war crimes we've seen in Ukraine over the past few days mean that there has to be an immediate ending to oil exports and imports of Russian from Russia and down the line gas interesting though Helena is that the biggest holdout is likely to be hungry we heard that the Hungarian ambassador in the meeting today was set against oil and gas sanctions and obviously these need to be done with unity amongst all 27. Helena? All right, our correspondent there, Shona Murray in Strasbourg for us. Shona, thanks a lot. It is 42 days since Russia invaded Ukraine. That is six weeks of

sentences.sentence: sanctions and promises to provide lethal support from political leaders in the West. But is it enough? Well, joining us now from New York is Ian Bremmer, president of the global risk consultancy Eurasia Group. Good to see you, Ian.

THE UKINIANS HAVE BEEN COURAGEOUS BUT ALSO BECAUSE NATO AND EVEN SOME NON-NATO STATES LIKE FINLAND AND SWEDEN HAVE PROVIDED A LOT OF DEFENSE EQUIPMENT DIRECTLY TO UKRAINE AND THAT CONTINUES TO ESCALATE TOO SO FRANKLY THE MORE MEANINGFUL RESPONSE HAS BEEN THE STINGER MISSILES THEY'VE BEEN THE DRONES IT'S BEEN THE JAVELIN ANTI-TANK MISSILES IT'S BEEN EVEN TANKS NOW COMING FROM THE CHEK REPUBLIC THE ECONOMIC SANCTIONS CONTINUE TO have been the drones, it's been the Javelin anti-tank missiles, it's been even tanks now coming from the Czech Republic.

sentences.sentence: The economic sanctions continue to escalate every day from the United States and from Europe and from other wealthy countries too.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: That's causing a lot of damage to the Russian economy, but it's not changing Russian behaviour one iota.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: What about on the diplomatic front, the response there then?

I mean, obviously, people have been talking about the toothlessness of the Security Council since 1949. The Soviets were given a permanent veto. Then we had a blockade in Berlin. And I think the UN founders were wondering to themselves, why the hell did we give that seat to the Soviets a little late now?

So do you think then that NATO will go ahead and send

sentences.sentence: heavier weaponry that Ukraine is calling for right now and that this could be a decisive factor in the war? I think tanks are heavier weaponry HEAVIER WEAPONRY, ABSOLUTELY.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I THINK THE REASON THAT YOU HAVEN'T SENT MIGS, AND THERE WAS A LOT OF BRUHAHA OVER WHETHER OR NOT THE POLISH GOVERNMENT WOULD SEND MIGS OR THE AMERICANS WOULD HELP TO SEND MIGS TO THE UKRAINIANS, BUT THERE HAVE BEEN SOME REAL QUESTIONS INSIDE THE WHITE HOUSE AS TO WHETHER THE UKRAINIAN PILOTS WOULD ACTUALLY HAVE THE ABILITY TO FLY THEM, DO THEY GET THEM IN THE AIR. I THINK THERE'S SOME REAL QUESTIONS INSIDE THE WHITE HOUSE AS TO WHETHER THE UKRAINIAN PILOTS WOULD ACTUALLY HAVE THE ABILITY TO FLY THEM, DO THEY HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE AND CAPACITY AND SECONDLY, WOULD THEY BE ABLE TO GET THEM IN THE AIR BECAUSE THEY HAVE TO TAKE OFF FROM UKRAINIAN BASES AND THE RUSSIANS HAVE AIR CONTROL.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: AND YOU DON'T WANT TO SEND THOSE WEAPONS TO UKRAINE AND THEN HAVE THEM COMPLETELY NOT BE EFFECTIVE. LIKE THAT MAKES THE WEST LOOK WEAKER. SO MY UNDERSTANDING IS THAT'S WHY THEY HAVEN'T PROVIDED THEM.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: BUT VIRTUALLY EVERY OTHER WEAPON SYSTEM IS BEING SENT.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: THE FRENCH PRESIDENT, EMMANUEL MACRON, NOW FACING A DIFFICULT ELECTION BATTLE, HE SAID A COUPLE OF WEEKS AGO THAT SENDING TANKS WAS TANTAMOUNT TO NATO BECOMING ACTIVE BELIGERENTS IN THE FIGHT.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: HE SAID NOTHING ABOUT IT SINCE THE CHEK REPUBLIC IS NOW ACTUALLY SENDING THEM IN THE tantamount to NATO becoming active belligerents in the fight. He said nothing about it since the Czech Republic is now actually sending them, and the Americans and Germans have said that they would support it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So clearly, we are seeing every week escalation in NATO's willingness to provide these weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The question is, if you're able, with this support, to take back all of the land that the russians have seized since february 24th does that mean that the russians give up and they stop fighting or does it mean that they expand and they start raining down more missiles on urban centers they use chemical weapons that's the question we have to ask. And that is the question when money for gas continues to flow into Russian coffers,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: which then helps to pay for a war on Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So do you think that sooner rather than later, EU governments may do without Russian gas?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, first of all, I want to be clear.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The same way that sanctions so far have had no impact on Russian behavior, I think cutting off gas would have no impact on Russian behavior in the near term. So if you told me that as of tomorrow, Germany is not getting any gas anymore from Russia, I don't think that's going to suddenly stop the Russians from attacking.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: That impact on their war coffers isn't suddenly going to make their military seize up. RUSSIA, I DON'T THINK THAT'S GOING TO SUDDENLY STOP THE RUSSIANS FROM ATTACKING. THAT IMPACT ON THEIR WAR COFFERS ISN'T SUDDENLY GOING TO MAKE THEIR MILITARY SEIZE UP.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: BUT I DO THINK THAT WHEN YOU HAVE A GOVERNMENT THAT IS BEING CREDIBLY ACCUSED OF WAR CRIMES ON THE GROUND WITH SATELLITE PHOTOS AND WITH HUNDREDS OF CIVILIANS THAT HAVE EYEWITNESS ACCOUNTS, THE FACT THAT THERE IS HUGE AMOUNTS OF MONEY GOING TO RUSSIA BEING PAID FOR BY EUROPE eyewitness accounts, the fact that there is huge amounts of money going to Russia, being paid for by Europe so that they can keep their economies humming along, I think that's becoming a very, very challenging behavior to continue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We know that if the Germans were to cut off that gas, it would be about a 3% hit to German GDP.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: That's significant, but it's nothing compared to the depression that the Greeks went through during the Eurozone crisis, and it's obviously nothing compared to what the Ukrainians are presently going through. Now, I'm not going to sit here and tell you that the American population would be willing to take that economic hit. They probably wouldn't, but I want to be clear. It's still the right thing to do, and I do think that we're going to go from cutting off coal which is easier and you can find more coal and you can pay a little more for it to cutting off oil which is harder but you can still pay for it you can find alternatives eventually we're getting the gas and the question only is how fast we move there is it in the next couple of weeks or is the next couple months or is the next year but sooner or later this gas is being cut off. This decision is going to be made.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ian Bremmer, always good to get your insights. Thanks a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good to talk to you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: False claims surrounding the war in Ukraine continue to spread, this time with a NATO commander caught in the middle.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Matthew in the Cube has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, Helena, since the mass killing of civilians in the Ukrainian town of Bucha, we're still seeing conspiracy theories and misinformation about the war spreading online.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And the latest of these concerns Lieutenant General Roger Cloutier, the US commander of NATO's Allied Land Command Force.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: There are misleading reports online that Cloutier had been captured by Russian forces in the besieged Ukrainian city of Mariupol, where he had reportedly been supporting Azov Nationalists, the group that the Kremlin has blamed on strikes and atrocities within Ukraine. Now these claims first appeared on far-right internet platforms, but they then spread to Twitter and Facebook where they were amplified by verified accounts, including this one that has more than 14,000 followers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But the allegations are false.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: If you go on to Lieutenant General Cloutier's own LinkedIn page, you can see that on his profile he has in fact posted an image of himself showing that he was attending, until very recently, an event in Turkey, Izmir, around 1,200 kilometres away from Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: In this image, you can see that he is surrounded by colleagues, clearly alive and well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And it was also posted on Twitter by NATO's Allied Land Command at the same time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: There is also no evidence of any NATO forces, soldiers or personnel in Ukraine at this moment, while the fact that member states have supported them with financial aid, no evidence, Helena, of any soldiers being deployed in Ukraine at this moment, while the fact that member states have supported them with financial aid. No evidence, Helena, of any soldiers being deployed in Ukraine and this kind of misinformation is going to continue spreading throughout the war. Well as ever Matthew, thanks for debunking it. Well you're up to date, I'll see you soon.
